 THAILAND SECONDARY EDUCATION QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PROJECT I. EDUCATION SECTOR A. Introduction Education and Economic Growth 1.1 During the past two decades, Thailand has undergone a rapid transformation from a predominantly agriculture-based society to an emerging industrial economy oriented towards manufacturing, services and external trade. In the 1980s, the emphasis of Government policy switched from import-substitution industrialization policies to export-oriented manufacturing. Real GDP grew at almost 11 % annually during 1987-93, and even as the economy slowed in 1991-1992, growth remained close to 8% p.a. The share of manufacturing in GDP rose from 16% in 1970 to over 27% in 1993, with most of the increase occurring in the late 1980s. During the 1990s, agriculture is expected to continue to fall as a proportion of GDP and manufacturing will continue to increase, while becoming more sophisticated and diversified in terms of both technology and products. Family ownership and extended family business organizations have given way to a variety of corporate entities with organized workforces, modern management systems, and increasingly sophisticated technological processes. The Government now makes few direct interventions in the market and leaves the leading role in decision- making to the private sector. Indeed, official policies actively encourage and support private enterprise. 1.2 Economic policy, and the structure and dynamics of the economy shape the nature of employment demand, thus playing an important role in determining the external and internal efficiency of the education system. The combination of sound macro-economic policies and favorable external circumstances has led to rapid changes in the economy of Thailand, with significant implications for future employment and for education policy. Rapid economic development has brought about an increasing demand for well-trained workers, technicians, and engineers in all fields. Fueled by private sector expansion, jobs are being restructured to accommodate new technologies, and there is a growing demand for employees with higher level skills. This has become particularly critical in the manufacturing sector where employment has grown steadily over the past decade and where rapid expansion is expected to continue. 1.3 To maintain strong momentum in its development, Thailand must address the emerging human-resource constraint. This takes the form of shortages of scientific and technical skills at all levels and inadequate enrollment in secondary education. The latter has resulted in a poorly educated workforce (over 80% of Thai workers have only
 - 2 - primary education or less) which reduces the trainability of workers and retards productivity growth. Secondary education plays a pivotal role in both the education system and the economy through providing qualified inputs to higher education and educated entrants to the workforce. Consequently, the need to expand secondary schooling and improve its quality are viewed as high priorities in Thailand. Furthermore, the long-term objective of becoming a technologically-advanced industrial country stresses the need to place special emphasis on education in the strategic subjects of science and mathematics and English. The System 1.4 Thailand's educational system, which is highly developed, can be divided into four levels: pre-primary, primary, secondary and tertiary (Chart 1). A strong commitment to equity has led to universal access to primary education, with high completion rates, as well as to the establishment of effective nonformal programs to increase adult literacy. In preparation for primary education, children enter the pre- school level at age 3 or 4 and then continue to primary school which requires 6 years to complete. Primary education is compulsory and free to all. Lower secondary education has been expanded to provide places for about half of the primary school graduates, and in principle there is an upper secondary place for each graduate of lower secondary education, half of which are in vocational schools and colleges. During the late 1980s, secondary enrollment rates in Thailand remained stagnant at around 30% of the age group. This was about half the rates in Malaysia and Indonesia and one-third of those in Korea and Taiwan, China. The Government has responded to the problem by extending the basic education cycle from 6 to 9 years. By 1997, all grade 6 graduates will enter grade 7 (para. 1.19). This policy will result in a corresponding expansion of upper secondary enrollments. 1.5 At the upper secondary level, a student may choose either the academic or the vocational stream. Vocational education is a major component of the educational system, accounting for about 45% of upper secondary enrollment in 1994. At the end of secondary schooling, about 43% of the students take the University Entrance Examination which screens entrants to degree programs in conventional public universities. Access to these universities has been tightly controlled and present enrollments of about 155,000 have remained relatively stable in recent years. Open universities have helped accommodate the high growth in tertiary enrollments, enrolling about 495,000 students in 1993 or 76% of total tertiary enrollment. 1.6 Responsibilities for educational administration and planning are shared among several central government agencies. Administration of primary, secondary and post-secondary (non-university) education, including teacher training, is the responsibility of the Ministry of Education (MOE). For supervisory purposes, the MOE has grouped the country's 75 provinces into 12 educational regions. At the higher
 -3 - education level, the Ministry of University Affairs oversees 21 public universities and 27 private universities and colleges. 1.7 The Government loosely controls private education which forms an important part of the education system and accounts for about 15% of primary, 14% of secondary, and 14% of higher education enrollments (Annex 1). Most private schools in Thailand are proprietary schools, with a few religiously-affiliated schools. There are two categories of private school: those offering general education and those offering vocational education. For the general stream, private schools range from kindergarten to secondary and their total number was 2,943 in 1993. There were 306 private vocational schools in 1993. The MOE also classifies private schools according to their financial standing: subsidized and non-subsidized. For private schools with a sound financial position, no subsidy is given and MOE does not control the ceiling of school fees. Private subsidized schools are of two types: (a) those receiving 60% of the cost per student; and (b) those receiving 40% of the cost per student. Fees in subsidized schools are controlled by MOE (para. 1. 14). B. Secondary Education in Thailand Structure 1.8 Secondary education comprises public and private schools, public and private vocational colleges, non-formal education delivery systems, and extended primary schools offering lower secondary classes in rural areas. All of these schools are administered independently of each other and serve different target groups. Within this structure, the majority of the public secondary school network is administered by the Department of General Education (DGE) of MOE. Secondary education is divided into two levels - lower secondary and upper secondary - each of three years' duration. Administration 1.9 Within the MOE, secondary education is managed by several departments (Chart 2). Among them, DGE is the largest provider of both lower and upper secondary education, managing 2,144 schools, of which 623 offer lower secondary education, 1,513 lower and upper secondary education, and 8 offer only upper secondary education. These schools enrolled approximately 2 million students or about 66% of the total secondary enrollment in 1994. With the new initiative to offer lower secondary classes in selected primary schools (4,300 out of 30,000 primary schools), the Office of the National Primary Education Commission (ONPEC) has become directly involved in secondary education. Both DGE and ONPEC have established provincial centers to coordinate school-related activities such as planning and implementation of DGE's and ONPEC's policies, preparation of budgetary proposals, general administration, training and supervision, and monitoring and evaluation of school performance.
 - 4 - 1.10 Decentralization is more advanced in primary than in secondary education. The provincial and district-level offices of the ONPEC have full authority to manage primary schools in their geographical areas. With respect to secondary education, however, the director of the Provincial General Education Office's main autonomous responsibility is to select and hire teachers. The director also has control over contracts not exceeding about $600,000 equivalent. 1.11 In addition to DGE and ONPEC, the Department of Vocational Education is also responsible for vocational and technical education at the upper secondary and post-secondary levels. The Office of the Private Education Commission supervises private primary and secondary schools but it does not intervene in the internal management of these schools.' The Department of Non-Formal Education is responsible for adult education which includes secondary education for out-of-school adults. Demonstration schools are under the jurisdiction of the Office of the Rajabhat Institutes Council (ORIC -formerly the Teacher Education Department) and individual university faculties of education.2 Finance 1.12 Public education is supported almost entirely by the central government. Fees are levied at the secondary and tertiary levels but cover only a minor proportion of recurrent costs. The share of the central government budget allocated for education grew from 17% in 1989 to 19.6% in 1993, and over the same period total education expenditure (public and private) increased its share of GDP from about 2.7% to 3.6%. Between 1964 and 1993, pre-primary and primary education received the largest allocation of the education budget (between 51% and 59%). During the same period, secondary education ranked second, receiving between 18% and 28% of the total education budget and this has been steadily increasing. In 1993, public expenditure by level of education was divided as follows: 49% primary (excluding pre-primary), 28% secondary, 17% higher and 6% other (including assistance to private schools and educational services and support). These proportions are in line with averages for other Asian countries. 1.13 As a percentage of the national budget, general secondary education represented 2% in the late 1960's, increased to a peak of 3.4% in 1978, and has remained around 3% since then. The trend of vocational secondary education followed the same pattern - it was around 4% in 1960s, peaked at above 4% in the late 1970s and has remained around 3.6% in the 1980s. Physical Facilities and Equipment. 1.15 The quality of rural secondary school facilities, particularly those limited to the lower cycle, tends to be much lower than in the larger urban schools. They often consist of a small permanent building to which the villagers have added temporary structures using local materials. Equipment is outdated, especially in the science laboratories (where these exist), libraries are poorly equipped and teaching materials are inadequate. As a result, it is difficult to attract qualified teachers and to teach the curriculum effectively. Many students from better-off rural families often bypass the small schools in their own localities to gain admission to the larger provincial schools, which offer both lower and upper secondary levels and higher-quality teaching. Physical facilities and equipment for science and language labs in the Rajabhat Institutes (RIs i.e. teacher colleges) are also inadequate by the standards of tertiary institutions and require upgrading. In the cases of libraries, learning resource centers, computer labs and multi- media educational technology, the level of provision and development is uneven across institutes but generally unsatisfactory. Curriculum 1.16 The Department of Curriculum and Instruction Development of the MOE is responsible for curriculum development and testing at both primary and secondary levels. The reform of 1978 introduced the 6-3-3 system and the "diversified" curriculum was implemented in all secondary schools. Since then secondary education has been vocationalized, starting first with lower secondary and followed by u3per-secondary in 1981. The Institute is involved in continuous curriculum development activities and related inservice teacher training and preparation of teaching materials. The terminal grade examination administered nationally has been abolished, and testing and examination are now administered internally by each school. In order to promote testing standards, schools are organized into clusters for closer testing collaboration. 1.17 Since Thailand has a local rather than a national assessment system, it is difficult to judge with any accuracy the overall level of student achievement in the secondary schools. However, the results of a 1983 study on academic achievement indicated that current levels of academic achievement were unsatisfactory.5 For example, lower secondary students scored below the 50th percentile in most subjects. Upper secondary students scored slightly above the average in social studies, rational problem- solving ability and Thai language, but had very low test scores in mathematics, science, and competence in the search for information. Although this study is dated, there is plenty of anecdotal evidence that a wide range of critics (especially academics, researchers and employers) view the academic achievement of secondary school students as unsatisfactory. This is particularly true of quantitative and communications skills. The 1983 study found that the main determinants of low quality in Thai secondary schools were: (a) the lack of qualified teachers; (b) weak curriculum; (c) inadequate supply of textbooks and other educational materials; and (d) the poor state of the infrastructure (buildings and laboratories). If as seems probable, there has been little improvement in student achievement over the past decade, these determinants of low quality still prevail and they provide a sure guide to the Government in identifying areas for quality improvement. 1.18 The problems facing mathematics and science teaching in Thailand are common to many countries. The low level of student achievement in these subjects in the secondary schools is attributable to weaknesses in the primary schools. In particular, primary school teachers are generalists and are said to be less comfortable teaching these subjects. Thus the lack of a firm foundation in science and math is carried upward into the secondary schools. Attention clearly needs to be given to strengthening the foundations of science and math in the primary grades but similar emphasis should also be given to quality improvement in the secondary cycle. It has been reported that in Thailand, poor teaching of science and math and the perceived difficulty of the subjects themselves, make them unappealing to students. However, this is not borne out by enrollment statistics. Access and Equity 1.19 In 1994, total secondary enrollment was about 3,430,000 (Annex 1, Chart 3). The vocational colleges accounted for about 45 of total upper secondary enrollment (Chart 4). About 26% of those graduating from these colleges at the certificate level join the labor force. In the "comprehensive" secondary schools,6 about 19% of the graduates enter the labor market. Thus the majority of graduates proceed to further education. During the 1980s, lack of development in secondary education resulted in a stagnant gross enrollment ratio of around 30%. This was the lowest among ASEAN countries and represented only about half of Korea's rate, when the per capita GDP in Korea was at Thailand's current level. Lack of investment in secondary education led to an under- educated workforce such that by 1990, 83% of workers had finished only primary education or less. This problem has been recognized by the Government and appropriate policies are being implemented (Annex 2). Compulsory education is being extended from six to nine years to cover the lower secondary cycle. The transition rate from primary to secondary, which was 86% in 1994, is planned to reach 100% by 1997. This represents remarkable progress since the transition rate was only 52% in 1990. This has been achieved through accelerated investment in school facilities, including the conversion of excess primary school capacity which has become available due to declining primary enrollments (following birth rate reductions). Under this program, about 4,300 primary schools will be expanded to teach the lower secondary grades 7-9. Capacity expansion has been accompanied by expanded inservice teacher training programs which include a three-year program to upgrade 45,000 primary teachers to lower secondary status. The result has been a substantial increase in the gross enrollment ratio in the secondary schools, which had reached 47% by 1992. 1.20. Secondary education in Thailand suffers from disparities in access that are common to many countries. Parents' occupational status, which strongly reflects educational level, is a major determinant of enrollment in secondary education. In 1985 for example, nearly 96% of the secondary-age children of professionals were enrolled compared with less than 15% of the children of farmers.7 Marked regional disparities in access were also evident. The transition rate from primary to secondary in 1985 was about 37% for Thailand as a whole but for the Bangkok metropolitan region it was nearly 99%. Only 2 (out of 12) non-metropolitan regions had rates above 60%. Although recent data on transition rates by region are not available, it is clear that given the rapidly 6 These schools were academically-oriented prior to 1978. Plans to expand access through classroom construction and accelerated teacher training will benefit mainly families in rural areas since enrollment rates are already high in Bangkok. But 77% of the population in Thailand is rural and the direct and opportunity costs of secondary schooling are a substantial burden on many families. Thus the Government's expansion plans for secondary education include subsidies to reduce the direct costs of schooling, which cover textbooks, school uniforms and dormitories. To provide further financial assistance, the Government has recently introduced a B 10 billion loan program for lower income families. The interest rate is 3% and repayments will be made through an additional income tax which is deferred until the borrower has obtained employment. The expansion of enrollments in rural schools would also be pursued through greater flexibility in class schedules and curriculum in order to fit schooling more closely to the rural environment. Teachers 1.22 Availability. In 1994 there were 108,130 teachers (56% female) in the public secondary schools of whom 5.3% held a master's degree or higher and 88.2% had a bachelor's degree. The overall student/staff ratio in secondary education, which is relatively generous by Asian standards, is increasing steadily as a result of the rapid expansion in secondary enrollments in recent years - from 17:1 in 1990 to 21:1 in 1994. This trend is likely to continue as enrollment increases outstrip teacher recruitment levels. In 1994, employment of secondary teachers increased by nearly 4% while enrollments expanded by around 11 %. The problem is more acute in the critical subjects of science, math and English where the stock of teachers is increasing at about 4% and enrollments at 14% per year. In 1993, the entire RI system produced only 240 graduate science teachers and 478 math teachers. While additional graduates are supplied by the university faculties of education, this would not have much impact on the teacher shortage which has been estimated by DGE and ONPEC to be 7,160 in mathematics and 5,230 in science. 1.23 Teacher Training in the Rajabhat Institutes. Teacher training is offered at the bachelor's degree, associate degree and diploma levels in the 36 Rajabhat Institutes. Secondary teachers require the four-year bachelor's degree to secure a teaching post. In recent years, the RIs have begun to diversify their programs in order to increase regional access to higher education. In addition to teacher education, a range of vocationally-oriented programs, such as applied science and technology, management, social development, agriculture, arts and journalism, is now offered. In 1994, the RIs had total enrollments of about 270,000, of which 121,500 (45%) were in education. The RIs
 - 9 - are under the control of the Rajabhat Institutes Council (RIC) which is responsible for overall policy, planning, budgeting, academic standards, etc. The Office of the RIC is responsible for the administration of the system. Each RI has a rector, a Governing Committee and an Academic Council to handle academic affairs. For the purposes of student selection and admissions, the 36 RIs are grouped into 8 United Colleges which provide a regional focus aimed at encouraging graduates to pursue careers in their home provinces. The RIs retain strong community orientation as reflected in their objectives which, in addition to training and retraining teachers, cover the provision of educational services to local areas, research and technical services, and technology development and transfer. 1.24 Although the RI's have evolved from teachers colleges into broader-based community colleges, education programs still represent the core activity. For secondary teachers, the B.Ed. degree is the basic qualification. This requires completing at least 130 credit hours in three broad areas: compulsory general education (40 credit hours) which includes courses in mathematics, science and English; a major subject (80 credit hours or more); and an elective (10 credit hours). This structure seems to be sufficient for the preparation of secondary school teachers in general, but it may not address adequately the problem of increasing shortages of math and science teachers. A trainee teacher taking these subjects as a major would complete at least 80 credit hours in addition to basic courses in the subjects taken as part of the compulsory program. This appears to be adequate preparation, at least in quantitative terms. But there remains the need to develop appropriate incentives to encourage more students to study these difficult but crucial subjects in the schools and then to encourage them to train as math, science and language teachers. This problem is reflected in the first choice of applicants for admission to the Mls in 1995 - a little less than 20% of applicants selected math or science (physics, chemistry and biology). Some attention is being given to these issues (para. 1.27). 1.25 The quality of teacher preparation is also an issue within the RIs. While standards vary significantly among the RMs, there is an urgent need to upgrade their academic and physical endowments. Staff qualifications are inadequate with only 4% of academic staff having doctorates and a further 30% having masters. Many of these degrees are outdated and, therefore, upgrading of college staff is vital to quality improvement. The increasing role of the RMs in the provision of research and educational services to the community, will also require greater numbers of academic staff with graduate degrees. Science laboratories and workshops have suffered from a lack of investment in facilities in recent years. Laboratory space needs to be expanded and workshops renovated in a number of RIs. Equipment provision also needs to be expanded and modernized. A combination of investments in staff upgrading and physical improvements would provide a basic quality-enhancing package for the RMs. While aimed at raising the quality of preservice teacher trainees, the measures would also strengthen the inservice training of serving teachers. The RMs have an important role to play in the provision of inservice training and this includes training for about 4,700 science and math teachers per year.
 - 10- Government's Policies and Plans 1.26 The Government is giving a high priority to the expansion of secondary education in response to its relative neglect in the past and this is reflected in substantial recent increases in the budget for DGE, which averaged 22% p.a. during 1990-94. This priority also reflects recognition of the crucial role secondary education plays in improving the quality of the workforce and in providing the basis for an expansion of higher education. As noted above, policies are being implemented for the rapid expansion of lower secondary education (para. 1.19), which will lead in due course to similar growth in the upper secondary cycle. However, rapidly expanding enrollments usually face the problem of maintaining quality. Here, the Government is pursuing a range of actions. There is a clear recognition that the key to quality lies in the preparation of well-trained teachers. Thus the teacher college system is being upgraded through raising the qualifications of academic staff, strengthening curricula and upgrading laboratories, workshops and libraries. This program is underway in 19 RI campuses and the proposed project is supporting it in the remaining 17 campuses. Inservice teacher training is also being expanded and improved to raise the competencies of serving teachers whose qualifications need updating. To complement the perfornance of better- trained teachers, attention is being given to ensuring that teaching facilities are well- equipped and there are adequate supplies of learning materials available. Ongoing efforts to review curricula are being reinforced by the authorization of private publishers to produce textbooks thus expanding the variety of materials available in the classroom. 1.27 The second major priority is the strengthening of education in math, science and English. These are regarded as key subjects within the education system which aims to create a scientifically literate population to serve as the basis for Thailand to develop into a technologically-advanced industrial country. The quality of education in these subjects is low due to the lack of qualified teachers and poorly equipped facilities. The Government is attempting to address these issues along the lines noted in the previous paragraph. In addition, a provincial network of specialized science (including math) and English language centers is being established to provide high-quality education in these subjects to selected students. Special scholarships will also be available in each center for students showing particular merit. However, there remain two major issues. First, there is the need to encourage more students to study these difficult subjects. Interest in science, math and foreign languages must be inculcated in students in the primary schools and appropriate measures taken to retain their interest in the higher grades and ultimately to encourage sufficient numbers to enter teaching. In 1994, a special program was inaugurated in DGE which provided funds (US$0.8 million) to promote science and math in the schools. Second, there is the need for the Government to develop measures to retain the services of teachers whose expertise is in great demand in the rapidly growing private sector and at salaries substantially above Government rates. Much more needs to be done to address this problem.

Bank's Experience in Education 2.1 The Bank has assisted the development of Thailand's education system under six loans/credits during the period 1966-82. Bank lending amounted to US$154 million or about 35% of total project costs of US$453 million. The overall direction of Bank lending under the six projects was consistent with education policy as it evolved under the first five national plans (1962-86). The first two projects focused on increasing the supply of technical manpower for industry and agriculture. Later projects had a broader educational focus and were consistent with the major educational reforms, introduced in 1978, which aimed at equality of educational opportunity, curriculum reform and improved management of the education system. Consequently, the later projects focused on the expansion of educational capacity in the rural areas, the introduction of diversified secondary curricula and the strengthening of education management.8 2.2 The first education project in Thailand (Ln. 471-TH) supported quality improvement and expansion of outputs in selected vocational institutions. The project financed construction, renovation and equipment for 24 trade, industrial and agricultural schools and an agricultural teacher training college. The project also included technical assistance for curriculum development and for upgrading teacher training. The PPAR for the project (Report No. 770, June 13, 1975) concluded that the project was implemented successfully. In general, overall enrollment and output targets were met and new well- balanced curricula were introduced. The technical assistance program was completed successfully and this was due, in part, to close cooperation between overseas advisers and local counterparts. Equipment procurement was delayed initially due to the late arrival of advisers and this delay was exacerbated by cumbersome procurement procedures. These problems were largely responsible for the project being completed four years behind schedule. Some items of equipment were judged to be too sophisticated for the schools and, in the case of some agricultural equipment, not relevant to local conditions. Some difficulty was experienced in retaining teachers with practical industry-related experience because of the demand for such skills in the labor market. 2.3 The second education project (Ln. 822-TH) assisted in upgrading education and research in agriculture and related fields in Kasetsart (Agricultural) University and also assisted its move to a new rural campus. The project financed site development, construction, furniture and equipment, and technical assistance for curriculum development, university management and project unit support. The NEC cites evidence that the difference in secondary level enrollment ratios between urban and rural districts increased between 1981 (25.2% difference) and 1985 (28.9% difference). In light of evidence suggesting t,,,at rural people would send their children to send their children to secondary schools if these were located close by, the MOE in 1988 announced its intention to extend universal education from 6 to 9 years on a non-compulsory basis. In 1989, the program was implemented on trial basis with two pilot projects operated by two MOE departments: ONPEC and DGE. Project on the Extension of Basic Education to Lower Secondary Level. In light of the Cabinet's decision to increase coverage beyond the primary level and to encourage rural children to remain in school at the lower secondary grades, DGE in 1987 initiated this project with the objective of establishing 718 schools in 38 economically disadvantaged provinces, and selected rural areas. Schools joining the project would establish a centrally located branch to offer lower secondary classes to children in surrounding villages. Schools were given limited freedom to design their own curriculum. The curriculum was presumably to emphasize vocational skills. Students were not required to attend school at the regular hours in order to introduce sufficient flexibility to help with farm chores or to travel long distances. About 71% of the pilot schools preferred the regular curriculum and several schools reverted to the regular curriculum after the first year. A number of direct subsidies were also introduced such as loans for textbooks, no uniforms, low-cost dormitories and exemption from fees. Pilot Project for Expansion of Educational Opportunities The rationale for this project, designed and implemented by ONPEC, is similar to that above, i.e. to see whether the three-year lower secondary education grades can be successfully joined with a primary school. This pilot project had as objectives. a) to identify an appropriate curriculum for a nine-year basic cycle; b) to raise the transition rate between Grades 6 and 7; and c) to ascertain parents attitudes toward lower secondary education particularly in rural areas.

doc.repnme: Thailand - Secondary Education Quality Improvement Project
doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Secondary Education Quality Improvement Project will be to assist in raising the quality of secondary education in science and mathematics through strengthening teacher education in these subjects. Specifically, the project aims to: 1) raise the qualifications of teaching staff in selected Rajabhat Institutes (RIs) (teacher colleges) and enhance their understanding of modern teacher education techniques; 2) reinforce quality improvement in the RIs through modernizing science laboratories and workshops with up-to-date equipment, expanding laboratory space and refurbishing workshops; 3) expand the capacity of the RIs to carry out in-service training of secondary teachers; and 4) enhance the RIs capacity to undertake research and provide technical services to the community. The project will comprise the following components: 1) civil works to construct new science laboratories and to refurbish workshops; 2) equipment to modernize laboratories and workshops; 3) equipment-related operations and maintenance expenditures; 4) an institutional development program consisting of fellowships and practical training for teaching staff, and in-service training for secondary teachers; 5) a research and technical services program which will include research grants and consultants to assist in the design of research projects and for new course development; and 6) assistance for project management and for the establishment of a monitoring and evaluation system.
